correct_answer: Physical evidence in forensic science can include fingerprints, DNA samples, firearms, and tool marks.

name: physical evidence

description: Physical evidence includes items such as fingerprints, DNA samples, firearms, and tool marks. name: Evidence

description: Evidence includes various items and materials collected from a crime scene, such as fingerprints, DNA samples, firearms, and tool marks. relation: tool mark --[Collected By]-> Forensic Scientists--description:Tool marks are collected by forensic scientists as part of their investigative process.-- name: tool mark
type: Forensic Evidence
description: A tool mark is an impression or trace left by a tool on a surface, which can be used as evidence in forensic investigations. relation: tool mark --[Analyzed Using]-> DNA Profiling--description:Tool marks can be analyzed using DNA profiling techniques if biological material is present.-- name: Forensic Scientists
type: Profession

type: Analytical Technique
description: Chromatography is a laboratory technique for the separation of mixtures. type: Analytical Technique
description: Mass spectrometry is an analytical technique that measures the mass-to-charge ratio of ions. It is used to identify and quantify substances in a sample. name: Scanning Electron Microscope
type: Instrument
description: A scanning electron microscope (SEM) is a type of electron microscope that produces images of a sample by scanning it with a focused beam of electrons. name: Microscopy
type: Technique
description: Microscopy is a technique that uses microscopes to view objects that are too small to be seen with the naked eye. relation: tool mark --[Analyzed Using]-> Microscopy--description:Tool marks can be analyzed using microscopy techniques to identify and compare the characteristics of the tool used.-- name: DNA Profiling

description: Spectroscopy is a technique used to analyze the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation.
